content:
I've formatted the variable names in the Constraints section.

I've also lowered the difficulty from Unselected (initially assigned as Very Hard) to Hard based on the latest success rate of 55% (458 out of 832 finished the puzzle). Depending on future statistics, the difficulty could be further lowered.

Updated the text to clarify the canal situation. I mean, the information was all there, but it was quite misleading to have a paragraph describing both the "greater than" and "less than" situations, and keeping the "equal to" one at the other end of the problem statement.

Also defined adjacency.

And approved.

Though I personally *would* actually like it better with aligned columns, for debugability. Let's see how this topic ends up.

Using multiple spaces between inputs to get a nicer alignment is not so nice for processing the input. I guess it can be ok, but since it's not like most other puzzles on the site, it needs to at least be specified in the description.

For me it is not really clear what happen when two adjacent cells have the same height.
(or am I missing something from the statement?)

There is no indication that the water can move to an adjacent square with the same height
(but from the test cases I understand it does)
In this case you need to build drain in any of these squares
In what language would it be (significantly) worse than with single space?

In JS and maybe others it's often a call like split(' ')
Splitting by regex instead, or adding a filter step to remove empty strings is not hard. So its not worse per se, just different than usual, and so unexpected without a mention in the description.
EDIT: but i see the test cases were modified to not use multiple spaces already

We seem to agree.

Marginally harder to parse, so indeed do warn about it, but I think it's worth the trouble.

Ok, but if I follow you, in this test case 

5 3
1 1 9 1 1
1 1 9 1 1
1 1 9 1 1

I understand that there should be 12 drains instead of 2, no?

Perhaps change the description to say something more similar to:

The water at each square flows down to each adjacent square of lower or equal height.
If there is a subset of adjacent squares with the same height, and if all of their adjacent squares have higher or equal height, then the water will accumulate.

I'm not sure if that's more clear or more convoluting, but if you use that as your definition of accumulate, and let drains be represented as 0s, you can rephrase the rest as:

Find the minimum number of drains that you need to add so that water will only accumulate in (and leak out of) drains.

That seems more precise (at least to me)
What do other people think?

Also you should probably define adjacent
Does the following need 1 or 5 drains?
3 3
1 5 1
5 1 5
1 5 1
